qas.question: What year did Victoria fall down the stairs at Windsor?

answers.text: at the wedding of Victoria's granddaughter Princess Victoria of Hesse
she fell down some stairs at Windsor

qas.question: Who died 10 days after Victoria's accident?

qas.question: What year didn't Victoria fall down the stairs at Windsor?
After her fall up the stairs, what health issue was Victoria plaged with thereafter?
Who lived 10 days after Victorias fall down the stairs?

context: On <a5_0>17 March <a0_0><b15_0>1883<b15_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>, <a10_0>she fell down some stairs at Windsor<a10_0/>, which left her lame until July; she never fully recovered and was plagued with <a1_0><b16_0>rheumatism thereafter<b16_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0>Brown<a2_0/> died 10 days after her accident, and to the consternation of her private secretary, <a3_0><a13_0>Sir Henry Ponsonby<a13_0/><a3_0/>, Victoria began work on <a12_0>a eulogistic biography<a12_0/> of <a11_0>Brown<a11_0/>. Ponsonby and Randall Davidson, Dean of Windsor, who had both seen early drafts, advised Victoria against publication, on the grounds that it would stoke the rumours of a love affair. The manuscript was destroyed. In early 1884, Victoria did publish More Leaves from a Journal of a Life in the Highlands, a sequel to her earlier book, which she dedicated to her "devoted personal attendant and faithful friend <a6_0>John <b17_0>Brown<b17_0/><a6_0/>". On the day after the first anniversary of Brown's death, Victoria was informed <a4_0>by telegram<a4_0/> that <a14_0>her youngest son, Leopold, had died in <a7_0>Cannes<a14_0/><a7_0/>. He was "the dearest of my dear sons", she lamented. The following month, Victoria's youngest child, Beatrice, met and fell in love with <a8_0>Prince Henry of Battenberg<a8_0/> <a9_0>at the wedding of Victoria's granddaughter Princess Victoria of Hesse<a9_0/> and by Rhine to Henry's brother Prince Louis of Battenberg. Beatrice and Henry planned to marry, but Victoria opposed the match at first, wishing to keep Beatrice at home to act as her companion. After a year, she was won around to the marriage by Henry and Beatrice's promise to remain living with and attending her.
